bug.short_desc: Wrong default kernel after a new kernel installation by dnf

long_desc.thetext:
Description of problem: After installing a new kernel with dnf, this new kernel is not the default kernel. I expect to see it as default at the top of the boot menu.
Version-Release number of selected component (if applicable):
grub2-tools-2.02-0.21.fc23.x86_64 grub2-2.02-0.21.fc23.x86_64 dnf-1.1.0-2.fc23.noarch
How reproducible: always
Steps to Reproduce: 1.Install new kernel with dnf 2. 3.
Actual results: New kernel it sitting on second position in the grub menu if booting
Expected results: first position
Additional info: 1.
/etc/default/grub:
GRUB_TIMEOUT=5 GRUB_DISTRIBUTOR="$(sed 's, release .*$,,g' /etc/system-release)" GRUB_DEFAULT=saved GRUB_DISABLE_SUBMENU=true GRUB_TERMINAL_OUTPUT="console" GRUB_CMDLINE_LINUX="rhgb quiet" GRUB_DISABLE_RECOVERY="true" GRUB_DEFAULT=0
2.
Running grub2-mkconfig helps only once.

(In reply to Joachim Backes from comment #0)
> Actual results: > New kernel it sitting on second position in the grub menu if booting
I have to correct myself:
The new kernel is on top position in the boot menu, but the previous kernel is still highlighted as default (pos 2):
Seems to be similar to BZ 1242315

Looks like grub2 changed the default behaviour of GRUB_SAVEDEFAULT from true to false.
At least I have the same /etc/default/grub file on F22 and F23 and it works fine on F22. On F23 grub always highlights and starts the oldest kernel available.
This is on a (U?)EFI machine.

(In reply to Christian Stadelmann from comment #3) > Looks like grub2 changed the default behaviour of GRUB_SAVEDEFAULT from true > to false. > > At least I have the same /etc/default/grub file on F22 and F23 and it works > fine on F22. On F23 grub always highlights and starts the oldest kernel > available. > > This is on a (U?)EFI machine.
My box is not an EFI machine :-)
I did a clean install, and GRUB_DEFAULT defaulted to "saved". I believe it used to default to "0".
Experiencing same issue on multiple Fedora-Server 23 machines. None are EFI.

Please attach /var/log/grubby and your relevant grub.cfg
I cannot reproduce with a fresh install of F23 Workstation and a subsequent dnf update kernel, new kernel is the one selected when I reboot.

Created attachment 1080321 /boot/grub2/grub.cfg
1. I'm not the only one having this problem (some users attached to this BZ). 2. For the desired info see the attachments!
I guess this is a duplicate of #1261569
Could it be connected to multibooting? I have Windows also installed on that machine.

(In reply to Piotr Drąg from comment #11) > Could it be connected to multibooting? I have Windows also installed on that > machine.
Same effect, but no multibooting on my box.

I have the same problem, and first noticed it on F22 about 6 months ago. I upgraded to F23 and hoped that the issue had been resolved but noted last night that it has not.
Problem: New kernel is installed and placed on the top of the boot menu, but the default is never updated to boot the new kernel. Also, on my system, the running kernel is never removed, so on F22 I had a 3.0.? kernel version running with a (possibly) 3.7 or 3.8 kernel installed.
Just now, with the latest kernel update I had 4.4.6 kernel installed but the 4.4.4 version was still marked as the default. I fixed the default entry using grub2 -o /boot/efi/EFI/fedora/grub.cfg and now the system boots with the correct (latest installed) kernel, so there is a workaround for the bug, but it is still irritating and should be fixed.
Reading the entries in /var/log/grubby I see something confusing in every entry that exists right now. EXAMPLE: ---------------------------------------------------------------------- DBG: 3970: Thu Mar 24 02:05:30 2016: command line: --grub2 -c /boot/efi/EFI/fedora/grub.cf g --efi --add-kernel=/boot/vmlinuz-4.4.6-300.fc23.x86_64 --copy-default --title Fedora (4.4.6-300.fc23.x86_64) 23 (Workstation Edition) --args=root=/dev/mapper/fedora-root --remove-kernel=TITLE=Fedora (4.4.6-300.fc23.x86_64) 23 (Workstation Edition) --make-default ----------------------------------------------------------------------
I note that the --add-kernel and --remove-kernel entries are for the same titled kernel package. In the man page for grubby it says that the kernel being added will never be removed, so maybe this is the area of grubby that has the problem causing this bug.
In reply to Piotr Drag, and like Joachim Backes, I am not multibooting on this system. Interestingly, my laptop, which does multiboot has never had this issue; Only my desktop machine has the issue.
